Award.AwardTitle: Type 1: Using Instructional Design Techniques to Create Distance CS Education to Support In-Service Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Georgia Research Corporation proposes to create a new distance-learning medium for computing education especially for in-service high school teachers based on ideas from instructional design and educational psychology. In-service high school teachers are particularly time-constrained (and thus need efficiency) and they are more metacognitively aware than other students (and thus able to better inform the project design). The new medium will combine multiple modalities, worked examples, and structure based on cognitive models of designers' knowledge. The research questions are (1) Will the teachers learn CS knowledge in this on-line setting? (2) Will the teachers will be more efficient at programming activities? and (3) Will the teachers will find the materials useful and satisfying? Because of its focus on teachers, the project can potentially have broad impact, in particular on the strategies for training the 10,000 teachers envisioned in the CS 10K Project. The project will establish models and design guidelines that can be used for the creation of other learning materials, including materials for students, for example, in the proposed new CS Principles AP course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project Type 1: Using Instructional Design Techniques to Create Distance CS Education to Support In-Service Teachers was about providing working teachers access to opportunities to learn computer science (CS) on-line. CS for All defines a national goal to give every student the opportunity to learn CS, but we have too few prepared teachers. Teachers are over-worked professionals. We have developed on-line ebooks to meet the design challenge of teaching CS to teachers in chunks that fit into their day. We aimed to create computing education for teachers that was so efficient and effective that they could become successful CS teachers in sessions of less than 20 minutes.  

We developed our ebook in iterations. The first version was reviewed and tested by expert high school CS teachers. The second version was with a group of eight teachers who had never taken CS at all. For the last few years, we have made the ebook available on-line, with all our measures of CS learning and attitudes built into the book. Hundred of teachers have used our ebook now to learn CS Principles. We find that the ebook does improve teachers’ learning of CS. More importantly, they come away from the ebook confident that they can teach CS. Our log file analyses indicate that the teachers do study the ebook in about 20 minute chunks.

We were careful and methodical in building our ebooks. We did experiments to test the design decisions and teaching methods that we built into our ebook. The results of those experiments are some of the most important outcomes from our project, because those design guidelines and on-line teaching methods can be (and have been) used by others. For example, we found that subgoal labeling significantly improves learning, retention, and transfer of CS learning, for both text-based and blocks-based programming languages. We have shown that Parsons problems is a particularly efficient form of CS practice. Learners gain as much from Parsons problems as from writing programs, but they take much less time.

The broader impact of our project is that we have helped new teachers get started with learning computer science, building their knowledge and confidence, in a way that fit into their lives. Those teachers have had an impact on many more students. We have shown that ebooks can be an effective tool for preparing teachers to learn CS.
